byline.contributor: Matthew L. Wald, Jackie Calmes and Eric Lipton contributed reporting.

abstract: Seven American makers of solar panels file a broad trade case against the Chinese solar industry, accusing it of using billions of dollars in government subsidies to help gain sales in the American market and dumping solar panels in the United States for less that it costs to manufacture and ship them; case seeks tariffs of more than 100 percent of the wholesale price of solar panels from China, which shipped $1.6 billion of the panels to the United States in the first eight months of 2011.
snippet: A trade case accuses Chinese makers of using government subsidies to help gain sales in the American market.
lead_paragraph: A trade case accuses Chinese makers of using government subsidies to help gain sales in the American market.

headline.main: U.S. Solar Panel Makers Say China Violated Trade Rules
headline.print_headline: 7 U.S. Solar Panel Makers File Case Accusing China of Violating Trade Rules
headline.seo: U.S. Solar Panel Makers Accuse Chinese of Trade Violations
